posts.post_content: The Disciple doesn't need infinite combos, just artifacts hitting graveyards anywere. Do it fast enough, or just drop more than one, and you win. Simple overpowered card, like many others from it's block, which had quite a few other commons banned (all artifact lands got the axe, mostly thanks to him and the fearsome monstruosity that is the [Arcbound Ravager](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arcbound Ravager) working together).

Posted By: Saxophonist (4/30/2012 9:18:27 AM)

posts.post_content:
@GrimjawxRULES: In mirrodin block there was no effective way to stop Ravfinity from destroying people in 3-4 turns. A typical run of the first turns was something along the lines of  
Turn 1 : Seat of the Synod, Ornithopther, Arcbound Worker  
Turn 2: Vault of Whispers, Arcbound Ravager  
Turn 3: Great Furnace, Frogmite, Thoughcast, Myr Enforcer, Disciple of the Vault  
Turn 4: Myr Enforcer, Swing with Ravager and Ornithopter, pump whichever they don't block for 8, they lose 8 life, drop a Shrapnel Blast and it's 21 points of damage.   
  
The issue was that there was no other deck in Block format that could even remotely begin to answer to Ravfinity's speed and damage. A lot of tournaments became a question of who's ravager could kill the other player first, and thus the game was no longer fun.
posts.html:
@GrimjawxRULES: In mirrodin block there was no effective way to stop Ravfinity from destroying people in 3-4 turns. A typical run of the first turns was something along the lines of
Turn 1 : Seat of the Synod, Ornithopther, Arcbound Worker
Turn 2: Vault of Whispers, Arcbound Ravager
Turn 3: Great Furnace, Frogmite, Thoughcast, Myr Enforcer, Disciple of the Vault
Turn 4: Myr Enforcer, Swing with Ravager and Ornithopter, pump whichever they don't block for 8, they lose 8 life, drop a Shrapnel Blast and it's 21 points of damage.

The issue was that there was no other deck in Block format that could even remotely begin to answer to Ravfinity's speed and damage. A lot of tournaments became a question of who's ravager could kill the other player first, and thus the game was no longer fun.

posts.post_content: @Axelle: I believe the problem is that without the coloured artifact lands, you can't just go 'I sac my board, you lose 1 life for everything that was sitting here. posts.post_content:
I disagree with almost everyone here; do read my entire reply though before just one-starring it.   
  
I think this is a well costed, or even \*mediocre\* card -had it been in a block that it wasn't so breakable in-! If I think of [blood seeker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=blood seeker), and say "well change it to artifacts and a near irrelevant creature type, and they have to go to the graveyard instead of enter play" it makes sense to cost this at any more than B.   
  
Artifacts dying \*seems\* difficult to build around. R&D were probably fine making this card \*EXCEPT\* that they printed loads of 0-cost or potentially 0-cost artifacts and free sacrifice outlets (that often even had bonuses, such as [Myr Retriever](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Myr Retriever).) Had this been in any other block you'd call it a mediocre common with some notable combos. Instead, it was part of one of the most one-sided decks ever to see standard and so is claimed to be amazing.  
  
This is an example of "live and learn", and I think the card was well designed and ba... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
I disagree with almost everyone here; do read my entire reply though before just one-starring it.

I think this is a well costed, or even *mediocre* card -had it been in a block that it wasn't so breakable in-! If I think of blood seeker, and say "well change it to artifacts and a near irrelevant creature type, and they have to go to the graveyard instead of enter play" it makes sense to cost this at any more than B.

Artifacts dying *seems* difficult to build around. R&D were probably fine making this card *EXCEPT* that they printed loads of 0-cost or potentially 0-cost artifacts and free sacrifice outlets (that often even had bonuses, such as Myr Retriever.) Had this been in any other block you'd call it a mediocre common with some notable combos. Instead, it was part of one of the most one-sided decks ever to see standard and so is claimed to be amazing.

This is an example of "live and learn", and I think the card was well designed and ba... (see all)
